review.title: Predictive modeling of die filling of the pharmaceutical granules using the flexible neural tree
review.abstract: In this work, a computational intelligence (CI) technique named flexible neural tree (FNT) was developed to predict die filling performance of pharmaceutical granules and to identify significant die filling process variables. FNT resembles feedforward neural network, which creates a tree-like structure by using genetic programming. To improve accuracy, FNT parameters were optimized by using differential evolution algorithm. The performance of the FNT-based CI model was evaluated and compared with other CI techniques: multilayer perceptron, Gaussian process regression, and reduced error pruning tree. The accuracy of the CI model was evaluated experimentally using die filling as a case study. The die filling experiments were performed using a model shoe system and three different grades of microcrystalline cellulose (MCC) powders (MCC PH 101, MCC PH 102, and MCC DG). The feed powders were roll-compacted and milled into granules. The granules were then sieved into samples of various size classes. The mass of granules deposited into the die at different shoe speeds was measured. From these experiments, a dataset consisting true density, mean diameter (d50), granule size, and shoe speed as the inputs and the deposited mass as the output was generated. Cross-validation (CV) methods such as 10FCV and 5x2FCV were applied to develop and to validate the predictive models. It was found that the FNT-based CI model (for both CV methods) performed much better than other CI models. Additionally, it was observed that process variables such as the granule size and the shoe speed had a higher impact on the predictability than that of the powder property such as d50. Furthermore, validation of model prediction with experimental data showed that the die filling behavior of coarse granules could be better predicted than that of fine granules.

metadata.title: Predictive Modeling of Die Filling of the Pharmaceutical Granules Using the Flexible Neural Tree

sections.text: In this thesis, a computer-aided intelligence (CI) called Flexible Neural Tree (FNT) was developed to predict the filling performance of pharmaceutical granules and identify significant variables in the filling process. FNT resembles the feedback-forward neural network that creates a tree-like structure through the use of genetic programming. To improve accuracy, the FNT parameters were optimized by using differential evolutionary algorithms. FNT-based CI model performance was evaluated and compared with other CI techniques: multi-layer perception, Gaussian process regression, and reduced pruning error of the tree. The accuracy of the CI model was evaluated experimentally with the filling quantity as a case study calculation. The nozzle filling experiments were performed with a model shoe system and three different varieties of microcrystalline cellulose (MCC), the MCC (102) and MCC (102) were measured at different velocities.

sections.heading: 2.1 Multilayer Perceptron (MLP)
sections.text: Normally, an MLP structure consists of three layers: an input layer, a hidden layer, and an output layer. Each layer of an MLP consists of several nodes, and each node receives real inputs and produces outputs based on the weighted linear combination of inputs. Subsequently, the size of the output of the node is calculated using a nonlinear activation function. In this work, a robust propagator algorithm was used to train an MLP [33].

sections.heading: 2.2 Gaussian process for regression (GPR)
sections.text: The GPR is a statistical technique that extends the multivariate Gaussian distribution. Let's make y = f (x) = φ (x) Tw be a regression model in which an input vector x = < x1, x2,.., xd >, x is mapped to a N-dimensional attribute space φ (·), and w is the learning component. Then, an average function m (x) and a covariance function k (x, x ′) define a Gaussian process gp (·). Mean and covariance functions are written as: m (x) = E [f (x)], k (x, x ′) = E [(f (x) − m (x ′)), (f (x ′) − m (x ′)]. and Gaussian process gp (·) can be described as: f (x) or gp (m (x, x ′).

sections.heading: 2.3 Reduced error pruning tree (REP-Tree)
sections.text: A Decision Tree resembles a tree-like structure whose non-leaf nodes are Decision Nodes. A Decision Node is tested (a binary decision) using an input tag and the leaf nodes are the results of the test. In the REP tree, a Decision Tree is created using the information available in training data, and then the leaves and branches of the tree are trimmed using the Reduced Error Intersection Method to avoid overfitting. In the Reduced Error Intersection Method, the tree nodes are trimmed until the accuracy of the prediction is not compromised. A detailed study of this algorithm is available in [20].

sections.heading: 2.4 Flexible neural tree (FNT)
sections.text: To minimize RMSE e converging to zero, an FNT adjusts its parameters using learning algorithms (such as genetic programming and differential evolution) by optimizing the components of the tree-like structure: internal nodes (computing nodes), branches (connecting weights), and leaf nodes (terminal nodes). In mathematical terms, a union of computing nodes F and T describes an FNT called S, where a computing node is an activation function, and a terminal node is an input.

sections.heading: 2.4.1 Structure optimization phase
sections.text: GP is a population-based evolutionary-inspired algorithm that uses genetic operators such as crossover and mutation and iteratively constructs an optimal tree-like structure (the structure that yields the least approximation error) using a huge topological search space [26]. In a crossover operation, the randomly selected sub-trees of two trees are replaced with each other, and in a mutation operation, a randomly selected sub-tree is either completely erased or replaced by a randomly generated sub-tree. In this work, the mutation operators were designed as follows: 1) Replace a terminal node with a new terminal node; 2) Replace all terminal nodes with new terminal nodes; 3) Grow a new sub-tree and replace a randomly selected functional node; 4) Replace a computation cell node with a terminal node. Since GP is an evolutionary-inspired algorithm, only the best input characteristics (prediction) are selected during the structural rotization phase.

sections.heading: 2.4.2 Parameter optimization phase
sections.text: DE is a population-based parameter optimization algorithm that uses the crossover operator and searches iteratively through a search space to optimize a vector that represents the parameters of a model [34]. Suppose H is the population of the tree parameter vectors. Therefore, DE tries to find an optimal tree parameter h к by using operators such as selection, crossover, mutation, and recombination. Therefore, for each iteration, the selection operator selects three random vectors from the population H: r1, r2, and r3, so that r1 6 = r2 6 = r3, and the vector g, which denotes the best solution in the population. Therefore, a new tree parameter vector hnew is calculated as: hnew r1 + F · (r1 − g) + F · (r2 − r3), if u < Cr1, if u ≥ C (7), is a random vector of the distribution between a − 1 and − rT. V1 and − r3 is a − rT.

sections.heading: 2.4.3 Limitations of FNT
sections.text: Compared to MLP, the basic limitation of the FNN is its source node, i.e. the root node of the FNT (tree-like structure). Since the tree can only have one root node, it is necessary to create several models for multiple output prediction problems. Furthermore, FNT can only offer models with multiple inputs and only one output, whereas MLP can offer models with multiple inputs and multiple output points. Furthermore, the proposed improvement of the FNT compared to other CI techniques consists in its structure optimization. However, with cross-validation (CV) methods such as k-fold CV, the structure is determined only once (only for the first fold) and for the rest of the (k − 1) folds only parameters have been optimized. However, if the structure is determined for all k folds, k different FNT models should be obtained.

sections.heading: 3 Experimental study
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: 3.1 Materials and methods
sections.text: Microcrystalline cellulose (MCC) in three different grades were selected as raw materials, including Avicel PH-101, Avicel PH 102 and DG. A tailor-made gravity roller compressor with two counter-rotating smooth rollers of 200 mm diameter and 46 mm width [35,36] was used for strip production, the roller gap was set at 1.2 mm and the roller speed at 1 rpm. Milling belts were sifted using a milling machine (SM100, Retsch, Germany) with a mesh size of 4 mm at a constant speed of 1,500 rpm. Grains were sifted into different size classes (0-90, 90-250, 250-500, 500-1000, 1000-1400, 1400-2360 µm), which were used for the nozzle filling experiments.

sections.heading: 3.2 Data collection
sections.text: The true density of the three MCC powders was determined using a helium pycnometer (AccuPyc II 1340, Micromeritics, UK), and the particle size analysis was performed using a size analyzer (Camsizer XT, Retsch, UK), and the experiments were conducted for 2-3 minutes and the data were collected; the mean diameter (d50), defined as the size below which 50% of the particles are located, was then determined; the filling tests were performed using a model filling system consisting of a shoe with pneumatic drive, a positioning regulator and a displacement meter [2]; for each granulate size class, experiments were performed at seven different shoe speeds ranging from 10 mm s − 1 to 400 mm s − 1; for each nozzle filling experiment, the powder mass inserted into the nozzle was weighted and the value recorded. − Each experiment was repeated three times.

sections.heading: 3.3 Predictive modeling
sections.text: The predictive modeling using the cochlear implant techniques discussed in Section 2 was performed in the following way: In 10FCV, a data set is randomized (mixed) first, then 90% of the data samples are used to form a model, and the rest of the 10% data samples are used for testing. This process is repeated 10 times, and each time a unique set of 10% data sets is selected to test the model. Hence, called 10FCV, the data set is randomly split into two sets. This process is 50% of the size of the entire data set. If the first set is used to form a model, then the second set is used to test the model.

sections.heading: 3.4 Input feature analysis of die filling experiments
sections.text: For this purpose, many FNT models were first created. Secondly, two performance dimensions were used: feature selection rate R and predictability value P. Feature selection rate R, which describes the total number of times a certain input mark was set, appeared in the list of prepared M models. The feature selection rate is defined as: Rj = 1MM ∑ i = 1I (Aj) (8), where Rj is the selection rate of the j input mark Aj-A, which is a power set P {true density, d50, granule size, shoe speed}, M is the total number of models in the list, and function I (Aj) is an identity function that returns "1" if the j input mark is set, the j input mark is selected, the Aj-th input mark is equal, the input function is Aj-th model, otherwise "0" becomes. Feature selection rate R is notable if the selection rate is 100%, and the selection rate is zero if the Aj is equal.

sections.heading: 4 Results and discussion
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: 4.1 Model Prediction
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: 4.1.1 Predictions using the 10FCV method
sections.text: Table 4 describes the performance of the best models created using FNT, MLP, GPR and REP tree. In Table 4, the models produced are arranged in descending order (highest accuracy to lowest accuracy) of their test correlation values. It can be observed that the performance of the models created using FNT (when comparing test accuracies, i.e. correlation values) was better than the other CI techniques. Therefore, the detailed observation of models No. 1, 2 and 3 created using FNT is advantageous. Model No. 1 (see: row 1 of Table 4) produces a high correlation coefficient (in the test kit), i.e. 0.95, indicating a high predictability of this model over 10% of unknown samples. However, the model complexity was also high as the overall functional nodes and the leaf nodes of the created model were 43.

sections.heading: 4.1.2 Predictions using the 5x2FCV method
sections.text: The models in Table 5 are arranged in descending order (highest accuracy to lowest accuracy) of their test correlation values. Similar to the models in 10FCV, the modelling in 5x2FCV and the performance of the models created with FNT exceeded the models created with MLP, GP and REP-Tree. This results in a detailed observation on models no. 7 and 8. Fig. 6 illustrates the performance of the model by means of regression (scattering).

sections.text: In Fig. 6, more than 50% of the test samples, i.e. 194 randomly selected test samples, were examined, analyzing the scattered chart and the target prediction plot. Similar to Fig. 5, the trend observed in Fig. 6 is that the prediction curve follows the target curve. However, the lower values and the outliers were out of reach of the prediction curve. The outlier in our data set is clearly visible in Fig. 6d. The outlier in our data set was due to noise or poor value observed during the filling process. Fig. 7 and Fig. 8 are the images of the models created, where the root node of the tree shows the results of the models and the leaf nodes (square boxes with numbers) display the input characteristics. In Fig. 7 and Fig. 8, the input characteristics, x1, x2, x3, and 50.

sections.heading: 4.1.3 Comparison between 10FCV and 5x2FCV methods
sections.text: Each 10FCV and 5x2FCV method has its advantages. This is why both methods have been used for the creation and validation of this work. In 10FCV, one model uses a large sample for training, therefore they have a higher representativity of the real world (data samples) during learning, i.e. the model is trained efficiently. Whereas in 5x2FCV, one model uses an equal proportionality of data samples for training and testing (smaller training samples than 10FCV, but larger test samples than 10FCV). Therefore, 5x2FCV have a higher generalization capability. Therefore, on the one hand, if a high test correlation coefficient is obtained using 10FCV, it shows that an effective predictive model can be created from the given dataset, but larger test samples than 10FCV.

sections.heading: 4.2 Feature analysis
sections.text: Because the evolutionary process was applied during modeling, the models created selected the input characteristics that had the highest predictability, so the RMSEs and the input characteristics determined by the models were included in a list. Subsequently, a comprehensive feature analysis was carried out. To this end, two performance measures were adopted: feature selection rate R as defined in (8) and feature predictability value P as defined in (10). The feature analysis was categorized into two phases 1) Identification of the individual input characteristics. Here, for (8) and (9) the feature set | Aj | was set to one, indicating that only one input characteristic was analyzed at a time. Since there were four input characteristics in our dataset, P-A, i.e. P was equal to the feature set of (A1, A2, A3, A4) was used.

sections.heading: 4.2.1 Identification of the significance of individual input features
sections.text: Table 6 describes the results of the characteristic analysis for each input characteristic. The significance of each characteristic corresponds to the true density, d50, grain size and shoe velocity. The characteristics true density and d50 represent the powder properties. While the grain size and shoe velocity represent the variables of the nozzle filling process, it can be observed that the selection rate and the predictability value of d50 (0.62069 and 0.58626) were higher than the selection rate and the predictability value of the true density (0.55173 and 0.54136). Therefore, the d50 as a powder property has a comparatively higher significance than the true density. Likewise, the process variable grain size was more influential than that of the shoe velocity. However, the difference in the significance level was marginal, but when all four input variables were compared, the process variables had a significantly higher selection rate and predictability rate on the powder properties.

sections.heading: 4.2.2 Identification of the best set input features.
sections.text: Table 7 shows interesting results, where it can also be stated that the predictability value of the subset A5 (process variable granulate size and shoe speed) and the subsets A1, A2, and A3 (with both process variables combined with one or two powder properties) was higher compared to the subsets A5 and A6 (subsets in which one of the process variables was not used for prediction).The subset analysis gave a clear picture. It is said that the predictability value of the subset A3 was highest, but the selection rate of the subset A1 was highest, suggesting that the evolutionary process often preferred the combination of whole characteristics, i.e. the subset A1. Among the subsets A1, A2, and A3, however, the selection rate of the subset A2 was higher, indicating that d50 had the ability to represent powder properties than the true density, but even here the difference was marginally higher (about four percent).

sections.heading: 4.2.3 Accuracy of Model Predictions
sections.text: Fig. 9 and Fig. 10 show the comparison between the experimental results of nozzle filling and the predicted results of Model No. 1 of the 10FCV method using FNT. This model was chosen because it has the highest value of R2, leading to a better match between experimental and predicted data. Specifically, Fig. 9 and Fig. 10 present the mass collected after each experiment as a function of the shoe speed of the three different MCCs powders for six different grain size ranges. It shows that there is a decrease in the mass that is deposited into the nozzle cubes with increasing shoe speed for all materials and granule sizes studied. In addition, a general increase in deposited mass was found at consistent grain grain size. MCC DG tends to show higher mass deposits compared to MCC PH 102 and MCC PH 101 for all materials studied and for all different size ranges c, with the exception of the ulum range (250 micrometer).

sections.heading: 5 Conclusions
sections.text: Two main methods were investigated, 10-fold cross-validation (CV) and 5x2-fold CV. Computer-assisted intelligence models (CI) were developed using FNT, multi-layer perceptron, reduced error interface tree and Gaussian process regression. It was observed that the flexible neural tree models performed better than other CI techniques. Furthermore, by examining the FNT models of each method, it was found that the 10-fold CV was a more efficient method with a higher correlation coefficient than the 5x2-fold CV. Experimental results were used as inputs and outputs of the FNT models. The constructed model efficiently predicted the deposited mass based on the knowledge gathered from the experimental data. Similarly, the feature analysis determined that the shoe velocity and pellet size were more important for controlling the deposited mass than the raw powder properties (which is considered easier for the filling density).

referenceMentions.context: The die compaction process consists of three primary stages: die filling, compaction, and ejection [1].
However, flow behavior during die filling process controls the tablet composition, the tablet properties as well as its segregation tendency [2–4].
However, flow behavior during die filling process controls the tablet composition, the tablet properties as well as its segregation tendency [2–4].
For instance, the effect of density and particle size on gravity and suction filling of several grades of microcrystalline cellulose powders were explored in [5].

The suction effect during die filling on a rotary press system was studied in [6], where the strong influence on the flow behavior of powders was observed due to air pressure build-up into an open cavity.
In [7], authors studied powder segregation behavior during die filling process for a mixture of fine and coarse powders from a stationary hopper.
For example, a study on die width proved that the filling density decreases proportionally with the die width [8].
, the filling density was observed to be increasing as the shoe speed was decreasing [9].
Additionally, in [10], authors studied the influence of different feed frames

Furthermore, in [11], authors proposed a new methodology based on the concept of critical shoe velocity to characterize powder flow, where a critical fill speed that suggests the minimum filling speed at which the die can be filled, completely.
[12] used a coupled discrete element method with computational fluid dynamics (DEM-CFD) to modeled die filling process, in which they explored the influence of powder properties (i.
[13] then investigated segregation induced by air during die filling, where DEM-CFD was used to simulate monodispersed mixtures.
Moreover, it is of commercial benefit for pharmaceutical companies to reduce the development time and costs with the contemporary improvement of the pharmaceutical process design [14].
To achieve these goals, the use of the multilayer perceptron (MLP) on a limited set of experiment data for predictive modeling can be of great benefit [15].
Additionally, use of computational intelligence techniques is advantageous for various pharmaceutical processes [16, 17].
Additionally, use of computational intelligence techniques is advantageous for various pharmaceutical processes [16, 17].
The common CI techniques such as multilayer perceptron (MLP), Gaussian process regression (GPR), and reduced error pruning tree (REP-Tree) solves several industrial and real-world problems [18].
• In REP-Tree, based on the dataset, a tree-like structure is created, where the tree’s internal nodes are binary decision nodes and the leaf nodes are the output nodes [20].
• The GPR is a Gaussian distribution based extension of linear regression technique [21].
A detailed description of these models is available in [23].
Moreover, the tree-like structure in the FNT is created using genetic programming (GP) [24,25].
Moreover, the tree-like structure in the FNT is created using genetic programming (GP) [24,25].
Therefore, the basic advantage of using FNT over MLP and REP-Tree lies in its ability of automatic adaptation into the tree-structure and the input feature selection with the help of GP [26].

It is known that for a good quality data, the predictive capability of MLP lies in its learning components, such as connection weights, network-architecture, activation-function, input features, and learning rules [32].
The design of FNT includes all these MLP-like learning components and offer an automatic adaptation of these components by using GP [24, 25].

A custom-made gravity-fed roll compactor with two counter rotating smooth rolls of 200 mm in diameter and 46 mm in width was used for ribbon production [35,36].

metadata.abstractText: In this work, a computational intelligence (CI) technique named flexible neural tree (FNT) was developed to predict die filling performance of pharmaceutical granules and to identify significant die filling process variables. FNT resembles feedforward neural network, which creates a tree-like structure by using genetic programming. To improve accuracy, FNT parameters were optimized by using differential evolution algorithm. The performance of the FNT-based CI model was evaluated and compared with other CI techniques: multilayer perceptron, Gaussian process regression, and reduced error pruning tree. The accuracy of the CI model was evaluated experimentally using die filling as a case study. The die filling experiments were performed using a model shoe system and three different grades of microcrystalline cellulose (MCC) powders (MCC PH 101, MCC PH 102, and MCC DG). The feed powders were roll-compacted and milled into granules. The granules were then sieved into samples of various size classes. The mass of granules deposited into the die at different shoe speeds was measured. From these experiments, a dataset consisting true density, mean diameter (d50), granule size, and shoe speed as the inputs and the deposited mass as the output was generated. Cross-validation (CV) methods such as 10FCV and 5x2FCV were applied to develop and to validate the predictive models. It was found that the FNT based CI model (in the cases of both CV methods) performed much better than other CI models. Additionally, it was observed that process variables such as the granule size and the shoe speed had a higher impact on ∗Corresponding author Neural Comput & Applic (2016) DOI:10.1007/s00521-016-2545-8 1 ar X iv :1 70 9. 04 31 8v 1 [ cs .N E ] 1 6 M ay 2 01 7 the predictability than that of the powder property such as d50. Furthermore, validation of model prediction with experimental data showed that the die filling behavior of coarse granules could be better predicted than that of fine granules.
